newsitem.title: GERMANY: Hypo shares drop on high risk provisions.
newsitem.headline: Hypo shares drop on high risk provisions.

text.p: Shares in Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechsel-Bank AG slipped on Wednesday after the German bank said its 1996 risk provisions rose around 50 percent from 1995 levels.

At 1300 GMT, Hypo shares were down 1.90 marks at 50.60 marks and near the session low so far at 50.50 marks after the Munich-based bank said the risk provisions reduced its 1996 operating profit gain of 17 percent to a loss of nine percent.

"The risk provisions were much higher than expected," said one Frankfurt bank analyst who asked not to be named. "It's a worry for investors based on the current economic conditions in Germany and the weak outlook for the real-estate sector."

In addition to concerns over the German real-estate industry and recessionary conditions in the building sector, the analyst said Hypo might have included write-downs on its stake in troubled brewery Brau und Brunnen AG.
Hypo bought a controlling stake in Brau in December with a view to selling its stake on to other investors. Shares in Brau und Brunnen have tumbled due to restructuring plans.
But one analyst, Dieter Hein at BHF Bank in Frankfurt, said Hypo's results were not disappointing because the market had expected banks to raise their risk provisions.

Hein also said investors should not overlook the 21 percent increase in commission income, which excluded the acquisition of Britain's Foreign & Colonial fund management group which Hypo plans to use as a base for expansion.
"The results are certainly not a disappointment and are relatively positive," Hein said.
